instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3435: What is 820-3435? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.820-3235: What is 820-3235? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.SMC_RESET: What is SMC_RESET? SMC_RESET is not a signal, it is an abbreviation for “SMC_RESET_L”, which is the signal someone is referring to when they type “SMC_RESET”  "SMC_RESET_L is a signal that resets the SMC when it is low(this is what the “_L” prefix means), and lets the SMC out of reset mode when it is high. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..
definitions.820-3209: What is 820-3209? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, PPV5 and PPV3 missing
threads.message:
Hi everyone, I just want to confirm that I have a case of bad smc? as I mentioned before I am in a remote area so it is a big deal to order parts. So I hoping someone can confirm that I have smc issue.

<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3235</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no green light not water damaged. doesnt turn on.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - present
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> - ok
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - missing
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - missing
I checked <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> and figure <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is missing, I checked resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> and it is fine(not broken)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, PPV5 and PPV3 missing
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, PPV5 and PPV3 missing
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 0.4v - it should L? or I look at it a wrong way?
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 8.2v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, PPV5 and PPV3 missing
threads.message: <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET</SIGNAL> should be high, there is your problem.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, PPV5 and PPV3 missing
threads.message: 0.4v points to bad SMC more than <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> missing because of the pullup resistor or <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> being bad. How does <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> area look?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, PPV5 and PPV3 missing
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 18131"]<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET</SIGNAL> should be high, there is your problem.[/QUOTE]

louise, <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> look fine, there is no signs of any kind water damage. <RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR> is fine.

I replaced <CHIP>U5510</CHIP> (SN0903049) with SN0903048 from <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, pin out and signals look the the same on the chip. I got 3.4 on <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET</SIGNAL>

I got green/yellow light. Macbook turns on BUT i have new issue, not sure were to start to diagnose it. It turns off randomly 1-4 min is max. Light on the chargers switches green when it turns off and then switches back to yellow. I can easily turn it on after it turns off. It looks like it simply loosing power. It does the same thing with or without battery.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, PPV5 and PPV3 missing
threads.message:
If the light turns green the SMC probably had a reset. So the problem was not solved, something got heated up and now <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET</SIGNAL> is intermittently being pulled low.
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET</SIGNAL> does go to the trackpad, so check cable/connector/trackpad for corrosion. Disconnect trackpad cable and see if board stays on, fan will run on full and system will run slow of course.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, PPV5 and PPV3 missing
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 18178"]If the light turns green the SMC probably had a reset. So the problem was not solved, something got heated up and now <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET</SIGNAL> is intermittently being pulled low.
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET</SIGNAL> does go to the trackpad, so check cable/connector/trackpad for corrosion. Disconnect trackpad cable and see if board stays on, fan will run on full and system will run slow of course.[/QUOTE]

Thanks, unfortunately disconnecting track pad flex doesnt make any difference, as well as there no corrosion that I could find.  Can it be smc it self since <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> close to it and could get hot

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, PPV5 and PPV3 missing
threads.message: Most likely crap under SMC then.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, PPV5 and PPV3 missing
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 18203"]Most likely crap under SMC then.[/QUOTE]

I removed smc and re balled it, not difference.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, PPV5 and PPV3 missing
threads.message: What is <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET</SIGNAL> now? There is not much to the <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET</SIGNAL> circuit

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, PPV5 and PPV3 missing
threads.message: I had 3.4v on <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET</SIGNAL> after <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> replacement. After reballing SMC I get the same thing. Macbook turns on and shots down every 2-4 min. Light turns green when it turns off. One time it stock on green light and will not turn on <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET</SIGNAL> was 3.4v no flexes connected to the board. In what causes green lights causes the board not to response to power button and auto turn on? Do you think SMC bad?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, PPV5 and PPV3 missing
threads.message: SMC is fine. Green light can only happen when SMC resets or power to SMC is lost. So either <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET</SIGNAL> is pulled low or 3V42 shuts down. Check J6100 for corrosion? Remove it anyway.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, PPV5 and PPV3 missing
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 18462"]SMC is fine. Green light can only happen when SMC resets or power to SMC is lost. So either <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET</SIGNAL> is pulled low or 3V42 shuts down. Check J6100 for corrosion? Remove it anyway.[/QUOTE]

J6100 doesnt have any visual problems with it, I removed it nevertheless. Macbook works fine since, I run it now for 3 hours, doesnt have any issue, I am hesitant , but it works, I will keep testing. 
Thanks Duke!
